newsitem.title: USA: February construction spending strongest in nearly a year.
newsitem.headline: February construction spending strongest in nearly a year.

text.p: Construction spending shot ahead at the fastest rate in nearly a year during February, the Commerce Department said on Tuesday, as warm weather fostered big gains in both private and publicly financed projects.

Spending jumped 2.3 percent to a record seasonally adjusted annual rate of $603.8 billion after a revised 0.3 percent January rise, when bitter weather slowed building activity. It far exceeded Wall Street economists' forecasts of a smaller 0.9 percent increase in February spending.

Department officials said February posted the strongest rise in monthly spending since a matching 2.3 percent rise in March last year. The last time there was a bigger spending jump was nearly three years ago, in March 1994, when it gained by 3.4 percent.
February construction spending was running nearly 11 percent above the February 1996 rate of $544.6 billion a year.
The government previously reported that January construction spending had risen by 0.4 percent, but it revised that down slightly.

The February pickup in construction activity was virtually across the board in both the private and government-financed sectors, offering further evidence of continuing solid economic growth in the first quarter.
Privately financed construction increased 1.8 percent to $456 billion a year in February following a 0.6 percent gain in January.

Spending on new housing was up 1.2 percent to a rate of $253.7 billion after a slight 0.1 percent rise in January. Construction of non-residential buildings like offices, hotels and hospitals climbed 2.5 percent to $158.5 billion following an even larger 3.2 percent increase in January.

Government spending on construction projects surged 4.1 percent to a rate of $147.9 billion in February after a 0.4 percent fall in January. Spending to build new public housing, schools, highways and streets, sewers and water treatment plants all picked up from January's pace.

After allowing for inflation, total construction spending increased 2.5 percent in February to a seasonally adjusted $522 billion annual rate following a 0.6 percent gain in January, the department said.
